articles.headline: A Hall of Fame Lawyer, a ‘Real Housewife’ and a Stunning Fall
articles.snippet: One of the country’s premier “toxic tort” lawyers is accused of misappropriating money from families of victims of the Lion Air crash that led to the grounding of Boeing’s 737 Max. And that’s just the beginning.
articles.abstract: One of the country’s premier “toxic tort” lawyers is accused of misappropriating money from families of victims of the Lion Air crash that led to the grounding of Boeing’s 737 Max. And that’s just the beginning.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, the movie “Erin Brockovich” helped make Thomas Girardi something of a folk hero.

articles.headline: Millions Flock to Telegram and Signal as Fears Grow Over Big Tech
articles.snippet: The encrypted messaging services have become the world’s hottest apps over the last week, driven by growing anxiety over the power of the biggest tech companies and privacy concerns.
articles.abstract: The encrypted messaging services have become the world’s hottest apps over the last week, driven by growing anxiety over the power of the biggest tech companies and privacy concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Neeraj Agrawal, a spokesman for a cryptocurrency think tank, has typically used the encrypted messaging app Signal to chat with privacy-minded colleagues and peers. So he was surprised on Monday when the app alerted him to two new users: Mom and Dad.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: F.B.I. Urges Police Chiefs Across U.S. to Be on High Alert for Threats
articles.snippet: A joint intelligence bulletin warned that the deadly breach at the Capitol would be a “significant driver of violence” ahead of the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
articles.abstract: A joint intelligence bulletin warned that the deadly breach at the Capitol would be a “significant driver of violence” ahead of the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The F.B.I. on Wednesday urged police chiefs across the country to be on high alert for extremist activity and to share intelligence on any threats they encounter, as the U.S. government issued a dire intelligence bulletin warning of potential violence ahead of the inauguration.
articles.byline: By John Eligon, Frances Robles, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: A Preordained Coda to a Presidency
articles.snippet: The impeachment of President Trump for a second time — in a Capitol ringed by troops — seemed like the almost inevitable culmination of four years that left the nation fractured, angry and losing its sense of self.
articles.abstract: The impeachment of President Trump for a second time — in a Capitol ringed by troops — seemed like the almost inevitable culmination of four years that left the nation fractured, angry and losing its sense of self.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not since the dark days of the Civil War and its aftermath has Washington seen a day quite like Wednesday.

articles.headline: As His Predecessor Is Impeached, Biden Tries to Stay Above the Fray
articles.snippet: The president-elect has long tried to keep from being sucked into President Trump’s dramas. He may find that posture hard to maintain when he takes office and the Senate puts Mr. Trump on trial.
articles.abstract: The president-elect has long tried to keep from being sucked into President Trump’s dramas. He may find that posture hard to maintain when he takes office and the Senate puts Mr. Trump on trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His fellow Democrats are red hot with rage after the assault on the Capitol, but President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has maintained a studied cool, staying largely removed from the searing debate that culminated on Wednesday with President Trump’s impeachment and keeping his focus on battling a deadly pandemic, reviving a faltering economy and lowering the political temperature.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: Trump Impeached for Inciting Insurrection
articles.snippet: President Trump became the first president to be impeached twice, after the House approved a single charge citing his role in whipping up a mob that stormed the Capitol. He faces a Senate trial that could disqualify him from future office.
articles.abstract: President Trump became the first president to be impeached twice, after the House approved a single charge citing his role in whipping up a mob that stormed the Capitol. He faces a Senate trial that could disqualify him from future office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump on Wednesday became the first American president to be impeached twice, as 10 members of his party joined with Democrats in the House to charge him with “incitement of insurrection” for his role in egging on a violent mob that stormed the Capitol last week.

articles.headline: Biden Outlines $1.9 Trillion Spending Package to Combat Virus and Downturn
articles.snippet: The president-elect detailed plans for an initial effort to fight the coronavirus and a subsequent one to address economic recovery.
articles.abstract: The president-elect detailed plans for an initial effort to fight the coronavirus and a subsequent one to address economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday proposed a $1.9 trillion rescue package to combat the economic downturn and the Covid-19 crisis, outlining the type of sweeping aid that Democrats have demanded for months and signaling the shift in the federal government’s pandemic response as Mr. Biden prepares to take office.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: Cash, Breakfasts and Firings: An All-Out Push to Vaccinate Wary Medical Workers
articles.snippet: Some staff in hospitals and long-term care facilities don’t want to take the Covid-19 vaccine. Their employers are trying to change their minds.
articles.abstract: Some staff in hospitals and long-term care facilities don’t want to take the Covid-19 vaccine. Their employers are trying to change their minds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anxious about taking a new vaccine and scarred by a history of being mistreated, many frontline workers at hospitals and nursing homes are balking at getting inoculated against Covid-19.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Robbins, Sabrina Tavernise and Sharon Otterman
